New-York Historical Society
Frey Family Papers MS 235
10.5 Linear feet (25 boxes)
1793-1917 (bulk 1825-1890) The Frey Family Papers primarily document multiple generations of the Frey and related Ludlow and Van Schaack families of upstate New York and elsewhere. The bulk of the collection is correspondence (16 boxes), detailing family news, health matters, and deaths; opinions on religion, politics, and the Civil War; financial, legal, and property issues and troubles; family history and genealogy.
Access Restrictions
Open to qualified researchers.
Portions of the collection that have been microfilmed will be brought to the researcher in that format and can be made available by Interlibrary loan.
Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.) Researchers on site may print out unlimited copies from microfilm reader-printer machines at per-exposure rates. See guidelines in Reading room for details.
Use Restrictions
Permission to quote from this collection in a publication must be requested and granted in writing. Send permission requests, citing the name of the collection from which you wish to quote, to
Library Director
The New-York Historical Society
170 Central Park West
New York, NY 10024
Preferred Citation
This collection should be cited as the Frey Family Papers, The New-York Historical Society.
Biographical Note
This collection contains items for over one hundred individuals. See family trees (available at repository) for the Frey, Ludlow, and Van Schaack families for relationships, birth and death dates. These trees were compiled from a variety of sources, including the items in the collection.
Many individuals in this collection had nicknames and used them often in correspondence. The following nicknames are commonly used:
Missing Title

Scope and Content Note
The Frey Family Papers primarily document multiple generations of the Frey and related Ludlow and Van Schaack families of upstate New York and elsewhere. The bulk of the collection is correspondence (16 boxes), detailing family news, health matters, and deaths; opinions on religion, politics, and the Civil War; financial, legal, and property issues and troubles; family history and genealogy. The larger correspondence subseries include letters from Caroline Frey Winne written from army postings in the western United States during the 1870s and 1880s; letters from Samuel Ludlow Frey concerning the family farm and finances; and letters from John Frey regarding financial, legal, and property matters. Letters from Henry A. Frey detail his ongoing financial, familial, and marital difficulties. Various members of the Ludlow family are also represented, presenting their opinions on religion, politics, and current events.
This collection also contains diaries; financial, legal, and property records; genealogies; poetry; ephemera; organizational and educational material; drafts of writings; notes, memoranda, and extracts; newspapers and clippings; sketches; one photograph; and documents relating to a southern gold mine.
The Frey Family Papers support research in the histories of New York State (major locations represented include Palatine Bridge, Oswego, New York City, Albany, Kinderhook); nineteenth century family life and religion; the Civil War; and late nineteenth century western history (letters of Caroline Frey Winne). This collection also supports research in nineteenth century women's history. The letters of Caroline Ludlow Frey, Christina Cantine, Elizabeth Van Schaack Frey, Anna Ludlow, Ellen Ludlow, and Helen Ludlow, for example, discuss family and social lives, health, religion, childrearing, politics, and current events (see subseries descriptions for details). In addition, the Frey Family Papers contain a number of letters written by children. See especially Caroline Frey ["Carrie" b.1868], Helen Frey, John Frey ["Johnny" d.1858], Wallace Jones, and Charles K. Winne, Jr.
Arrangement
Correspondence arranged by sender. See container list for other series arrangements.
The collection is organized into the following seventeen series:

Letters to various family members dealing with family news, his work in the insurance industry, politics (particularly the election of 1860 and his enthusiasm over Lincoln), New York State excursions, the Civil War (Frey joined a Zouaves regiment, the 110th NYSV, in the Union Army summer of 1862), job prospects after the war, weather.Letters sent: Frey, Augustus B.1851-1862 July32Letters sent: Frey, Augustus B.1862 Sept.-187133Letters sent: Frey, Augustus B.1873-1883, 1903, 1917, undated34Subseries 28. Frey, Henry A., 1854-1884, undated ["Harry"]
Scope and Contents note
Letters to family members (most from Cleveland, Chicago, and Indiana) regarding family matters, his involvement in coal dealing, various entrepreneurial schemes, continual financial troubles, his attempts to enlist in the Union army, involvement in the Civil War, and in a gold mining venture at King's Mountain, NC. Frey also discusses familial discord, his debts to family members, accusations of impropriety, the dissolution of his marriage, and his emotional troubles. There is a gap in the letters from 1864 to 1866.Letters sent: Frey, Henry A.1854-185848Letters sent: Frey, Henry A.1859-186049Letters sent: Frey, Henry A.1861-1862 July410Letters sent: Frey, Henry A.1862 Aug.-187351Letters sent: Frey, Henry A.1874-187852Letters sent: Frey, Henry A.187953Letters sent: Frey, Henry A.1879-1884, undated54Subseries 36. Letters about family history, the death of his son.Letters sent: Frey, J.W.1858-185958Subseries 40. Frey, John [1806-1886], 1825-1886, undated
Scope and Contents note
Early letters detail his schooling, legal studies, his religious conversion at the age of twenty, and his 1828 marriage to Caroline Ludlow. In late1829, Frey accompanied his brother Henry to St. Augustine, FL, where the latter hoped to find respite from his lung ailment. Letters from Florida describe local population, food, Henry's health and subsequent death in early 1830. Frey's letters from 1830 to 1865 concern his finances, family, legal matters, property and land sales, the farm and planting, limestone and willow trees, family strife with the Beardslees, and the Civil War. There is a gap in the letters from 1845 to 1850, and from 1865 to 1872. After 1872, and a move to Hoboken, N.J., the letters concern the death of his wife (1873), his job at the Custom House, New York City, grandchildren, family news and health. There is also a gap from 1874 to 1877.Letters sent: Frey, John1825-1827 May59Letters sent: Frey, John1827 June-1829 Oct510Letters sent: Frey, John1829 Nov-183061Letters sent: Frey, John1831-184462Letters sent: Frey, John1850-1858 Feb63Letters sent: Frey, John1858 June-1860 June64Letters sent: Frey, John1860 July-1866 May65Letters sent: Frey, John1861 June-1862 April66Letters sent: Frey, John1862 June-186571Letters sent: Frey, John1872-187872Letters sent: Frey, John1879-188673Letters sent: Frey, JohnUndated74Subseries 41. Scope and Contents note
Most letters are written from Decatur, AL, and detail family matters and history; opinions on the Civil War, Southern and national politics; local customs, gardening, weather, farming, keeping chickens, and cotton.Letters sent: Frey, Samuel C.1852-187678Subseries 46. Frey, Samuel Ludlow, 1850-1917, undated ["Ludlow," "Lud"]
Scope and Contents note
Early letters written from school in Poughkeepsie detail his studies, local events, family news (esp. Ludlow family), weddings and social events, dental procedures, and weather. Later letters from Palatine Bridge discuss the family's financial troubles, deaths, land sales, the Civil War, farming and winemaking, and health. There is a gap in the letters from 1865 to 1872. After 1872, his letters continue to describe finances and debt, farming, health, and local news. Also under discussion are his mother's death in 1873, other deaths, politics, the railroad, Henry A. Frey's continual financial troubles, digging for Indian relics, articles written and submitted for publication, and family news. There is another gap in the letters from 1883 to 1895. Later letters concern family and local history, and a dispute with the New York Central & Hudson River Co. over a fence and drainage on Frey property.Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow1850-186179Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow1862-1865710Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow1872-1873 Apr81Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow1873 May-1874 Apr.82Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow1874 May-1875 June83Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow1875 July-187684Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow1877-187885Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow1879 Jan-Oct86Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow1879 Nov-188087Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow188191Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow1882-1883, 188992Letters sent: Frey, Samuel Ludlow1895-191793Letters sent: Frey, Samuel LudlowUndated94Subseries 47. Scope and Contents note
Early letters (through 1831) are written from Philadelphia; from 1836 on, written from Oswego, NY. They discuss family news and troubles, health problems (particularly his eyes), local politics, businesses, including insurance, gas and railroad, politics, Ulysses S. Grant, Roscoe Conkling, racial issues (c1875), the Beecher scandal, his daughter Ellen, the last illness and death of his wife, Nancy Douglas Ludlow (1877), physical ailments.Letters sent: Ludlow, Samuel Baldwin1825-1841121Letters sent: Ludlow, Samuel Baldwin1846-1860122Letters sent: Ludlow, Samuel Baldwin1865-1872123Letters sent: Ludlow, Samuel Baldwin1873-1875124Letters sent: Ludlow, Samuel Baldwin1876-1878125Letters sent: Ludlow, Samuel Baldwin1879-1881, undated126Subseries 74. Scope and Contents note

Scope and Contents note
Letters to John Frey regarding Frey's finances, national politics, land sales, the Wagner family, the Civil War, Frey's legal matters, foreclosure.Letters sent: Wagner, P.J.1839-1873146Subseries 95. Winne, Caroline Frey Giddings, 1851-1899, undated ["Carrie," "Sis"]
Scope and Contents note
On microfilm: Dec. 1874-May 1880, Misc. Reel #61. July 1883-July 1887, Misc. Reel #19.
Letters written from Nebraska (1874-1878) were published in Nebraska History, Spring 1981, pp. 1-46.
Caroline E. Frey married Col. Grotius R. Giddings in 1862; he died in 1867. She married army surgeon Dr. Charles K. Winne in 1874.
Chronology of postings:
1861-1865Fort Trumbull, CT; New Orleans, LA; Oswego, NY; Palatine Bridge, NY1874 Dec.-1877 Nov.Sidney Barracks, NE1877 Nov.-1878 Jan.Fort McPherson, NE1879 May-1880 MayFort Washakie, WY1880 Aug.Fort Brady, MI1880 Oct.-1883 Mar.Fort Schuyler, NY1883 July-1883 Nov.Fort Winfield Scott, CA1883 Dec.-1884 Sept.Angel Island, CA1884 Oct.-1885 JulyBenicia Barracks, CA1885 July-1887 JulyU.S. Arsenal, Benicia, CA1887 Sept.-1890 MayFort Wadsworth, Staten Island, NY1891 Nov.Fort Snelling, MN1899 JuneFort Crook, NE
Early letters detail family news and her first husband's illnesses, and her mother's death (1873). Letters from Nebraska (12/1874-1/1878), describe local Native Americans, a meeting with Sitting Bull (2/13/1875), her husband's family troubles, her pregnancy and difficult childbirth (1875), violent incidents in the frontier town, health and small pox, complaints about army life and servants, the death of Crazy Horse (letter 9/9/1877), the birth of Charles K. Winne Jr. (9/30/1877), her husband's position in the army and his opportunities for reappointment. Letters from 1878 through mid-1883 discuss the baby, the journey to Wyoming, and her health; and contain descriptions of Wyoming, including a Shoshone Sundance (5/25/1879). An eighteen-page letter of 6/17/1883 and postcards detail her transcontinental railroad journey to California. Letters from California contain family news; reports of her son's education; reactions to the deaths of Henry A. Frey and her father, John Frey; descriptions of the weather, local life, numerous post transfers; opinions on the Chinese and Chinese servants (see especially letters of 1/3/1886, 4/19/[1887], 10/9/1887).
Note: a number of Caroline Frey Winne's undated letters have been tentatively dated, in pencil and in brackets, by a previous processor. The accuracy of these dates has not been verified, and these letters have been moved into the undated folders at the end of the subseries.Letters sent: Winne, Caroline Frey Giddings1851-1860147Letters Winne, Charles K., 1875-1877, 1886
Scope and Contents note
Most letters concern Caroline Frey Winne's pregnancy in 1875 and her poor condition following childbirth (baby was stillborn or died soon after). Later letters discuss the birth of Charles K. Winne, Jr. and family matters.Letters sent: Winne, Charles K.1875-1877, 1886167Subseries 97. Winne, Charles K. Jr., 1886-1911 ["Bopper"]
Scope and Contents note
Mostly childhood letters about pets, excursions, family, botany. Later letters discuss family visits.Letters sent: Winne, Charles K., Jr.1886-1911168Subseries 98. Wynkoop, Francis, 1838-1879
Scope and Contents note
Letters concern John Frey's finances, family matters (both Frey and Wynkoop), mortgages, fishing, and the varnish business.Letters sent: Wynkoop, Francis1838-1879169Subseries 99. Letters sent, unidentified, 1799-1912, undatedLetters sent: unidentified1799-18591612Letters sent: unidentified1860-1912, undated1613Subseries 102. Envelopes and stamps, 1893-1902, undated
Scope and Contents note
Alienated and blank envelopes; loose stamps.Envelopes; stamps1893-1902, undated254Series II. Diaries, 1821-[18]92, undatedSubseries 1. Samuel Ludlow Frey, 1859-1886
Scope and Contents note
Brief entries in pocket diaries concerning family matters, weather, social events, playing cricket, politics, finances, fishing, botany, Indian relic hunting, and articles written. Most entries simply detail daily farm activities such as plowing and planting.Diaries: Samuel Ludlow Frey (19 volumes)1859-188617Subseries 2. Caroline Ludlow [Frey], 1821-1826
Scope and Contents note
Spiritual diaries. Many are unbound, loose sheets. Only the first of these diaries is signed by Caroline Ludlow [Frey], the rest are assumed to be hers. Entries are reflections on religion and particular sermons.Diaries: Caroline Ludlow [Frey]1821-1826181Subseries 3. [Helen Ludlow], 1860
Scope and Contents note
Pocket diary probably belonging to Helen Ludlow. Entries detail daily household and social activities, family news, her emotional state, reading, cooking, trips to Niagara and Boston, her father's sermons, and what appears to be an aborted courtship. Notes in the back of the volume include a list of daily chores, poetry, and finances.Diaries: [Helen Ludlow]186017Subseries 4. John Frey, 1829-1830
Scope and Contents note
John Frey's brief travel diary of his excursion to St. Augustine, FL with his ailing brother Henry.Diary: [John Frey], travels to St. Augustine, FL1829-1830182Subseries 5. Unidentified, 1829-[18]92, undated
Scope and Contents note
This subseries includes an unidentified author's weather diary for Jan., 1829, an unidentified author's brief travel diary for a trip to Virginia in 1892, and a mostly blank pocket diary of an unidentified author.Diary: unidentified, weather1829 Jan. 1-12182Diary: unidentified, travel diary to Va.1892182Diary: unidentifiedUndated17unknown containerSeries III. Financial Records, 1799-1912, undated
Scope and Contents note
This series contains Frey family account books, bills, loose accounts, bonds, promissory notes, receipts, printed reports, and calculations. Sorted by last date on item. Printed reports include insurance company statements and annual reports for the town of Palatine, NY. Account books include two 1863 volumes (possibly belonging to Henry A. Frey) detailing items (alcohol, food, cigars) sold to Union troops.Financial Records1799-1821183Financial Records1821-1828184Financial Records1829-1832185Financial Records1833-1834186Financial Records1835-1836187Financial Records1837-1844188Financial Records1845-1861191Financial Records1862-1865 July192Financial Records1865 Aug.-1867193Financial Records1871-1904194Financial Records: Calculations and undatedUndated195Financial Records: Printed reports1856-1912196Financial Records: Account book1812-1837197Financial Records: Account book1863 Apr.-Nov.198Financial Records: Account book1863 Apr.-Sept.199Financial Records: Account book1865 Oct.199Series IV. Legal Material, 1799-1865, undated
Scope and Contents note
This series includes indentures, bonds, court papers (including copies of opinions), notes, drafts of wills, agreements, estate inventories and papers, notices, articles of agreement. Many of the items concern John Frey's financial and legal troubles, especially the undated material.Legal material1799-1842201Legal material1846-1865202Legal materialUndated203Series V. Land and Property Records, 1806-1873, undated
Scope and Contents note
Includes surveys, memorandum, records of patent lots, articles of agreement, indentures, and sales of Frey family land. Also one folder of house plans.Land and property records1806-1847204Land and property records1849-1873, undated205Land and property records: house plansUndated206Series VI. Genealogical Material, undated
Scope and Contents note
This series includes family trees for the Van Schaack, Ludlow, and Herkimer families, as well as a North family register, and notes on the Herkimer, Yates, and Roach families.Genealogical materialUndated207Series VII. Poetry, undated
Scope and Contents note
This series contains copies of published poems, as well as poetry that is most likely original, including FitzHugh Ludlow's "Epistle from a brave of the Ludlow Tribe to a distinguished Mohawk," written for his cousin, Samuel Ludlow Frey.PoetryUndated208Series VIII. Ephemera, 1818-[1904], undated
Scope and Contents note
Includes invitations, announcements, and programs for various events including balls, festivals, weddings, meetings, concerts, tournaments, and historical commemorations (including the 1876 centennial and an anniversary celebration of the Emancipation Proclamation at Hampton Institute); an announcement for the sale of the Frey family farm; death notices; advertisements for barbed wire fences, farm machinery, health remedies, wine making paraphernalia; circulars for beehives and globes; direct mail from the Republican State Committee; calling cards; catalogs for an antique auction with notes; and a railroad timetable for the Chicago, Burlington, and Quincy Railroad.Ephemera: invitations, announcements, programs1854-1891, undated209Ephemera: announcement, sale of Frey farm18562010Ephemera: death notices1818, [1873]-1886, undated2011Ephemera: advertisements1884, undated2012Ephemera: circulars, direct mail1880-1899, undated2013Ephemera: calling cardsUndated2014Ephemera: auction catalogs[1904]2015Ephemera: railroad timetable18782016Series IX. Organizational Material, 1880-1911, undated
Scope and Contents note
This series contains material relating to the meetings of various organizations, including the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the Oneida Historical Society, the Scotch-Irish Society of America, and the Daughters of the American Revolution. Also included is the handwritten, undated "Eighth Annual Report of the Female Praying Society."Organizational material1880-1911, undated211Series X. Educational Material, 1833-1857, undated
Scope and Contents note
This series contains report cards, an achievement certificate for Frey children, and two school notebooks.Report cards, certificate1851, 1857, undated212Notebook: Ceylina North, "Practical Arithmetic"1833213Notebook: unidentified [possibly Elizabeth Frey], "Deffinitions," geographical termsUndated214Series XI. Drafts, 1799, 1852, undated
Scope and Contents note
Drafts for Samuel Ludlow Frey's, The Story of Our River and The Colonel and the Major. Also a draft of an article probably written by Frey, "Were They Mound Builders," and a brief, early essay of his (possibly for school) entitled "Old, times." Drafts of writings in the hand of John Frey discuss politics, slavery, homeopathy, and insurance. This series also includes what appear to be drafts of addresses, in the hand of John Frey. Topics include temperance, farming and agriculture, slavery, religion, politics, and education. As one document names Frey as recorder for an unnamed society, these addresses are not necessarily his own work. In addition, three drafts of works by unidentified authors are located in this series.Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 1-2Undated215Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 3-4Undated216Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 5-6Undated217Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 7-8Undated218Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 9-10Undated219Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 11Undated2110Drafts: SLF, The Story of Our River, Ch. 1-3Undated221Drafts: SLF, The Story of Our River, Ch. 4-5Undated222Drafts: SLF, The Story of Our River, Ch. 8-9Undated223Drafts: [SLF], others1852, undated224Drafts: bulk [John Frey]Undated225Drafts: addresses, bulk [John Frey]1799, undated226Drafts: addresses [John Frey]Undated227Series XII. Notes, Memoranda and Extracts, 1849-1891, undated
Scope and Contents note
Many of the loose sheets are unidentified. They include extracts from plays, speeches, newspapers; quotations; axioms; religious notes; fragments of writings on various topics; lists; exercises. Notes attributed to Samuel Ludlow Frey have been previously separated. They consist of notes about history and books; quotations; and extracts.
Bound notebooks include Samuel Ludlow Frey's "Flora of Palatine"; an unidentified volume containing "Speech of Hon. Hen. Wilson," and religious reflections and notes; an unidentified volume containing notes on the history of upstate New York; Mary Tank's notebook of pressed flowers; and a blank notebook belonging to John Frey.Notes, memoranda, extractsUndated228Notes, memoranda, extractsUndated229Notes, memoranda, extractsUndated2210Notes, memoranda, extracts: [John Frey]Undated2211Notes, memoranda, extracts: [Samuel Ludlow Frey]Undated231Notes, memoranda, extracts: [Samuel Ludlow Frey]Undated232Notes, memoranda, extracts: [Samuel Ludlow Frey]Undated233Notes, memoranda, extracts: [Samuel Ludlow Frey]Undated234Notebook: Mary Tank, pressed flowers1849235Notebook: Samuel Ludlow Frey, "Flora of Palatine"1875-1891236Notebook: unidentified, "Speech of Hon. Hen. Wilson," religious reflections and notesUndated237Notebook: unidentified, historical notes of upstate New YorkUndated237Notebook: John Frey, blankUndated237Series XIII. This series includes documents relating to Henry A. Frey's involvement in a gold mining venture in South Carolina, including gold bullion deposit receipts, copies of indentures, articles of agreement, leases, and surveys.Gold mine documents1844-1866238Series XIV. Contains newspapers and clippings, mostly from upstate New York publications, many of which contain articles by Samuel Ludlow Frey. Also reprints of articles, most from the Utica Morning Herald, regarding Samuel Ludlow Frey, his interests, and the Oneida Historical Society.Newspapers, clippings241Newspapers, clippings242Newspapers, clippings243Newspapers, clippings244Newspapers, clippings245Reprints246Series XV.
